questions.question: Which of the following checks to see if the assessable record exists for the demand and creates an assessable record if none exists?
answers: A. Validate Assessment Metrics for Demand
B. Auto Business Rule for Assessments

comments.content:
B. Auto Business Rule for Assessments - Checks if the assessable record exists for the demand and creates an assessable record if none exists.

now learning Project Portfolio Management (PPM) Implementation: Module 3: Idea and Demand Configuration (Washington)

B. Auto Business Rule for Assessments 
You can check these 4 business rule SPM implementation module3 DEMAND > Assessments

replies: Auto Business Rule for Assessments , correct is B.

comments.content:
Answer is D 
Read below for definitions
Create onDemand Assessment
Creates assessments for authorized users after a demand has moved from the submitted state to the screening state.
Update Demand State
Updates the demand state to Qualified after all assessments are completed. For example, Risk must be between 0 and 10 or Strategic Alignment must be between 0 and 10.
Validate Assessment Metrics for Demand
Validates the score values for a demand to be within the maximum and minimum values.
Auto Business Rule for Assessments
 Checks if the assessable record exists for the demand and creates an assessable record if none exists.
Idea and Demand Configuration (Utah) under the business rule
Answer found, now learning Project Portfolio Management (PPM) Implementation 3: Idea and Demand Configuration (Utah) under the business rule heading.

D is correct
-	Assessable Record Check: When a specific event or action occurs, such as the creation of a demand record, ServiceNow checks if an assessable record exists for that demand
-	Assessable Record Creation: If no assessable record is found, the "Assessment Creation on Demand" feature automatically generates a new assessable record associated with the demand
As per the course, Auto Business Rule for Assesments: Checks if the assessable record exists for the demand and creates an assessable record if none exists.

questions.question: Where is the normalization process used?

comments.content:
Calculated value that measures the Rating relative to the weights of categories used to assess the record evaluated.

The normalized value is calculated as follows:

Normalized value = Rating x (Associated category weight / Sum of weights of all categories the source record has category results for in this assessment group)

Example: A source record has four associated category results in assessment group ASG0000907, one for each of these categories:
Importance Rating (weight = 10)
Product Reliability (weight = 9)
Company Alignment (weight = 9)
Compliance Score (weight = 9)
If this source record's category result for Product Reliability has a Rating of 7.81, the normalized value calculation is:

7.81 x [9 / (10+9+9+9)] = 1.9
